results.title: The Die hard: the legend of Lasseter's lost gold reef
results.creator_credit: Venture Films, David Crocker and Supreme Films
results.brief_description: Reconstructs the story of Harold Lasseter’s prospecting expeditions in Western Australia and his later searches for the reef of gold he claimed to have seen in 1897, up to his death in the attempt in 1930.

results.title: The Diaries of Vaslav Nijinsky
results.creator_credit: AFFC, Illumination Films (AU), MusicArtsDance Films, Paul Cox and Aanya Whitehead
results.brief_description: Poetic musing of a life drawn from diaries left by one of the world’s most famous ballet dancers. Vaslav Nijinski was a dynamic force in ballet, wanting to broaden the possibilities of dance - perhaps ahead of his time. Imagery from the natural world mixed with interpretations of ballets, historical documents and re-creations of the people and times of his life, are all lead by rich voice of Derek Jacobi, who narrates as Nijinsky reading directly from the dancer’s diaries. Thoughts on his career, his sexuality, his mental health and general place in the world reveal some of the inner turmoil of the man and his artistic temperament. His career was short lived as Nijinsky became mentally ill, remaining in an institution until his death in 1950. Directed and edited by Paul Cox “The Diaries” is a work that demonstrates the filmmaker’s passion for the dancer and writer that was Nijinsky. A co-production of Australia, Sweden, Germany and Netherlands. Original music by Paul Grabowsky. Cast includes Chris Haywood, Delia Silvan, Hans Sonneveld, Oliver Streeton, Jillian Smith.

results.title: The Diagnosis of childhood schizophrenia
results.creator_credit: Brooklyn Juvenile Guidance Centre and Affiliated Film Producers
results.brief_description: Traces the step-by-step procedure of screening clinical data in order to establish the diagnosis of childhood schizophrenia: a process involving a review of the pertinent historical material, psychological test findings, clinical observations, and the noting of the absence of significant medical, neurological, and laboratory test results, followed by a differential diagnosis to rule out clinical syndromes with which childhood schizophrenia is commonly confused.

results.title: The Devils
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Ken Russell and Robert H Solo
results.brief_description: This erotic adaptation of Aldous Huxley’s “The Devils of Loudon” is based on a 17th Century incident of diabolical possession which affected a religious community in France. For Russell the foundations of religious hysteria is in the repressed sexuality, and the feudal heirarchy, of Catholic monastic life. Oliver Reed plays Father Grandier who refuses to collborate with the agents of Louis XIII who are attempting to challenge the power of the traditional clerical nobility. When Grandier is accused of sorcery by the Mother Superior of the Convent in Loudon (Vanessa Redgrave) a show-trial is commenced in which the Convent is exorcised of its “demons”. Russell, whose richly hallucinatory Catholic imagination has always been under-rated by Anglo-saxon critics, is able to give expression to both the pleasure and danger involved in sexuality. This fascinating film, anchored by the sharp spiritual insight of Huxley’s original novel, is one of the director’s best films.

results.title: The Devil at your heels
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Adam Symansky, Bill Brind and Robert Fortier
results.brief_description: The late Ken Carter’s long-time obsession to be the world’s greatest daredevil is the subject of this feature length documentary. Seen are the five years of preparation that went into raising one million dollars, building a rocket-powered car, and constructing a ten-storey take-off ramp for his attempt to jump a car across a mile-wide stretch of the St. Lawrence River. A portrait of a stunt driver who made his living by risking his life. Photography by Barry Perles. Narrated by Gordon Pinsent. (Awards: Genie, Toronto)

results.title: The Devil and Daniel mouse
results.creator_credit: Nelvana, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Patrick Loubert, Michael Hirsh and Clive A Smith
results.brief_description: Using traditional cell animation, the timeless story of the person who sells his soul to the devil in return for present success is told. Jan and Dan are a not-too-successful folk singing duo, when Jan signs a contract with the devil to become a famous rock singer. When the devil comes to collect Jan, Dan demands a trial. Photographed by Lenora Hume; script by Ken Sobol; edited by Bob Ablack; music by John Sebastian.

results.title: The Devil's gateway
results.brief_description: Blood and the Imaginary of blood, both play a prominent part in Christian worship. The most common experience of blood - women’s menstrual bleeding - is still widely regarded as ‘unclean’. Explores the power and impact of the taboo on menstruating women still practised in society and four major religions - Orthodox Christianity, Islam, Hinduism and Orthodox Judaism. The fears women experience and the guilt and shame induced by centuries of suppression masquerading as religious laws are examined. In this program, women from all cultures describe their personal and social consequences of menstruation.

results.title: The Development of transportation
results.creator_credit: ERPI Classroom Films, Electrical Research Products and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A study of the development of transportation in the USA during the past 150 years. The spread of railway and highway networks over the geographical barriers of the continent, and the principle stages of the development of the locomotive and automobile engines are dealt within detail; air transport, and its potentialities form the final part of this survey.

results.title: The Development of instruments and their music: a symphony is recorded
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Open University and Alasdair Clayre
results.brief_description: Shows the rehearsal and performance of C.P.E. Bach’s Symphony in D by the Croyland Chamber Orchestra, as it was recorded for the Open University gramophone record “The Rise of the Symphony.” Examines the steps taken to achieve a musically authoritative recording of an 18th century orchestral work.
